ã€

#â€‹773 â€” February 17, 2026

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

TanStack Hotkeys: A Type-Safe, Cross-Platform HotkeyÂ Library â€” The TanStack family gains a new member: Hotkeys, an alpha-stage universal keyboard interaction toolkit. It handles cross-environment quirks, supports multi-step sequences (like Vim commands or cheat codes), and can record user shortcuts. Here's the fullÂ pitch.

TanStack LLC

ğŸ’¡ Being in alpha, the focus in the docs is on React for now, but it's not React only, and they're looking for help with Solid, Angular, Svelte, and VueÂ adapters.

Still Writing Tests Manually? Meticulous AI IsÂ Here â€” Notion, Dropbox, Wiz, and LaunchDarkly have found a new testing paradigm - and they can't imagine working without it. Built by ex-Palantir engineers, Meticulous autonomously creates a continuously evolving suite of E2E UI tests that delivers near-exhaustive coverage with zero developerÂ effort.

Meticulous sponsor

Announcing TypeScript 6.0 Beta â€” v6.0 is largely a â€œtime to clean up your tsconfigâ€ release, designed to bridge the transition to the Go-powered native TypeScript 7 later this year. Be aware of some tweaks, like types defaulting to [] and --strict now being true by default, among many more breaking changes andÂ deprecations.

Microsoft

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ“Š Hot on the heels of the recent State of JS survey results come the State of React results.

  • ğŸ¤– Google shows off a preview of WebMCP, an attempt to create a standard way for web sites to offer up abilities for AI agents to use.

RELEASES:

  • Biome 2.4 â€“ The formatting/linting tool can now handle embedded CSS & GraphQL in JS files, improves Vue and Svelte support, and adds HTML accessibility lintingÂ rules.

  • React Native 0.84 â€“ Hermes V1 is now the default JS engine on iOS and Android, iOS ships with precompiled binaries, and ReactÂ 19.2.3.

  • Node.js 25.6.1 (Current) and Node.js 24.13.1 (LTS)

  • sql.js v1.14.0 â€“ SQLite compiled to JavaScript.

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

Experiments with CodeMirror â€” CodeMirror is one of the most robust code editor components out there (weâ€™ve just used it while rebuilding our newsletter editor!) and itâ€™s very extensible too, as seen in this walkthrough of building a VSCode-like â€˜change reviewâ€™ feature forÂ it.

Antonio De Lucreziis

How to Make an HTTP Request in Node.js â€” A comprehensive guide to using fetch in production, tackling timeouts, streaming requests and responses, retries, concurrency, mocking, and more. Most of this is useful in the broader JavaScriptÂ context.

Luciano Mammino

One Database for Transactions and Analytics. No Pipelines â€” TimescaleDB extends Postgres so analytics runs on live dataâ€”no sync lag, no drift, no second system. TryÂ free.

Tiger Data (creators of TimescaleDB) sponsor

Implementing Virtual Scrolling at Billion-Row Scale â€” A walkthrough of tackling the numerous challenges involved in building a table component (HighTable) that handles billions ofÂ rows.

Sylvain Lesage

JS-Heavy Approaches Aren't Compatible with Long-Term Performance Goals â€” A web performance engineer at Automattic makes the case against JS-heavy architectures and in support of a more server-centricÂ approach.

SÃ©rgio Gomes

ğŸ“„ Fun with TypeScript Generics â€“ Not your typical entry-level tutorial but a dive into a niche useÂ case. Adam Rackis

ğŸ“„ Building Bulletproof React Components â€“ Elegant, no-nonsense tips from the co-creator of SWR. Shu Ding

ğŸ“„ How Rolldown Works: High-Performance Code Splitting with BitsetÂ Logic Atriiy

ğŸ“„ Angular Bindings: What Are They and How Do I Use Them? Bo French

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Electrobun v1: A Bun-Based Desktop App Approach â€” An introduction to a cross-platform runtime for JS/TS desktop apps. It uses the OSâ€™s default web renderer (like Neutralinojs) with Bun as the engine and bundler behind the scenes. The resulting bundles are as small asÂ 12MB. (Homepage and GitHub repo.)

Blackboard

ğŸ’¡ Electrobun's creator â–¶ï¸ shows it off in this 4 minute video.

Console Ninja: Inline Logs & Smarter Debugging â€” See console output, runtime data, and errors next to your code, shared with your AI. Rethought, redesigned, and rebuilt in v2 for faster JavaScript debuggingÂ workflows.

Wallaby Team sponsor

fetch-network-simulator: Intercept fetch to Simulate Poor NetworkÂ Conditions â€” The heart of this is a library that intercepts fetch and applies rules to do things like drop random requests, delay them, or slow them down, so you can see how resilient your appÂ is.

Karn Pratap Singh

Peek: A Lightweight Library for Smart Page Header Behavior â€” You can see it in action on the page. Itâ€™s â€œsmartâ€ in that it will differentiate between small insignificant scrolls and intentional ones. You can customize the thresholds and delays and it works with any framework. RepoÂ here.

Chad Pierce

ğŸï¸Â Rari: Runtime-Accelerated Rendering Infrastructure â€” A React Server Components framework but with a Rust-powered server runtime, aiming for higher throughput and lower latency. The getting started guide will help you get theÂ idea.

Ryan Skinner

Broad Infinite List: A Bidirectional Infinite List for React and Vue â€” Smoothly stream logs, feed updates, or chat history in both directions without layoutÂ shifts.

suhaotian

  • ğŸ“Š Perspective 4.2 â€“ Interactive analytics and data viz component for large/streamingÂ datasets.

  • Dockview 5.0 â€“ Zero dependency layout manager supporting tabs, groups, grids, and splitÂ views.

  • â™Ÿï¸ Stockfish.js 18 â€“ A WASM port of the Stockfish chess engine you can use fromÂ JavaScript.

  • Ohm 17.5 â€“ Parsing toolkit for building parsers, interpreters,Â etc.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ”¥JSNation 2026 lineup: Matt Pocock, Luca Mezzalira & more speakers revealed! Letâ€™s talk modern web dev in beautiful Amsterdam thisÂ June.

ğŸ“¸ Add robust 1D/2D barcode scanning to your web app with STRICH. Easy integration, simple pricing. Free trial and demo appÂ available.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

  • ğŸ¨ Three years ago we linked to DPaint.JS, a web based image editor modeled after the legendary 1980s Amiga and PC graphics editor Deluxe Paint. Many side projects like this fizzle out, but not DPaint! v0.2.0 has been released after two years with support for animations, pen support, texture brushes, andÂ more.

  • almostnode is an experimental project that brings a Node.js runtime environment into the browser. The demo on the homepage isÂ neat.

  • ğŸ“Š Data from over 100,000 sites was boiled down into this useful report on modern CSS usage. The median number of CSS rules per site was 2,802, with one page somehow using 210,695Â rules!

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ Not content to just port Quake to run in the browser, the creator of Three.js has now attempted a Descent port too (source).

  • ğŸ¤– Can you recreate something like SQLite with a swarm of agents? Kian Kyars had a try, as part of an agent coordination experiment.

  • Cloudflare is rolling out a feature to allow agents to fetch Markdown directly from Cloudflare-powered sites.

JavaScript Weekly

npmx: A New npm Registry Package Browser â€” A smooth, fast way to browse packages on the official npm registry. Itâ€™s certainly fast, smooth, and you see more info up front and center - check out the axios page for example. â€œWeâ€™re not replacing the npm registry, but instead providing an elevated developer experience through a fast, modernÂ UI.â€

npmx

The Most Loved JavaScript Course Year AfterÂ Year â€” JavaScript: The Hard Parts is rated 4.92 on average by thousands of developers. Build real mental models for how JavaScript works, from execution context and closures to async behavior and modern languageÂ features.

Frontend Masters sponsor

ğŸ“ŠÂ The State of JS 2025 Survey Results â€” The results of the annual survey are here, compiling the opinions of over 12,000 JavaScript developers into a flurry of charts in areas as diverse as language pain points, frontend framework choices, build tool usage, how much of their code is AI generated, and what non-JS/TS languages theyÂ use.

Devographics

ESLint v10.0.0 Released â€” This long-awaited milestone completes the removal of the legacy eslintrc config system, introduces a new config lookup algorithm that starts from the linted file (great for monorepos), adds JSX reference tracking to fix scope analysis issues, andÂ more.

ESLint Team

IN BRIEF:

  • webpack shares its 2026 roadmap. Topics include support for a universal target to compile code to run on numerous runtimes, building TypeScript without loaders, CSS modules without plugins, andÂ more.

  • VoidZero shares its January 2026 recap covering updates to Oxlint, Oxfmt, Vitest, andÂ more.

  • Deno Deploy is now GA as a platform for easily deploying JS/TS apps to the Web. There's also a 45 minute video where Ryan Dahl shows itÂ off.

  • ğŸ¤¯ Promethee provides UEFI bindings for JavaScript. Write a UEFI bootloader in JavaScript instead of C?Â Yep.

  • Ember 6.10 â€“ Cleanups and modernization for the stable, battle-testedÂ framework.

Mat Marquis

â–¶Â Â Evan You on Vite, Rust and the Future of JSÂ Tooling â€” The Vue.js creator joined the Better Stack podcast to discuss his path from building Vite to founding VoidZero and developing a Rust-based JS toolchain.

Debugging a Next.js Production Issue with Sentry Logs, Not JustÂ Errors â€” Lessons from a Next.js production debugging session where understanding behavior mattered more than stackÂ traces.

Sentry sponsor

item.title: ã€Babel 8 RC Arrives, Gatsby Lives, Lodash Resetsã€‘Babel 8 RC åˆ°æ¥ï¼ŒGatsby å¤æ´»ï¼ŒLodash é‡ç½®
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹771 â€” February 3, 2026

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Four Heavyweights Drop Updates

Four stalwarts of the JavaScript ecosystem all shipped notable releases this week, and odds are you're using at least one of them:

  • Gatsby v5.16 proves Gatsby, once considered neck-and-neck with Next.js in the React world, is not 'dead'. The headline feature is React 19Â support.

  • Babel 7 just shipped its final release. "After years in the making, Babel 8 is finally ready," in release candidate form, atÂ least.

  • Rspress 2.0 is a major release for the high-performance Rust-powered, but JavaScript-facing, static siteÂ generator.

  • Lodash 4.17.23 sounds minor, but it's a 'security reset' for the still heavily used utility library and is designed to provide a base for a longerÂ future.

Only Fools Write Tests â€” Modern engineering teams like Notion, Dropbox, Wiz, and LaunchDarkly use Meticulous to maintain E2E UI tests that cover every edge case of your webÂ app.

Meticulous sponsor

ğŸ¦€Â OpenClaw: The Runaway AI Assistant â€” An intense week for a new open source TypeScript project: 150k stars on GitHub, hordes buying Mac Minis to run it, two rebrands (it was originally Clawdbot), and an ecosystem of projects the agents use autonomously (e.g. an entire social network). Another example of TypeScript at the heart of the AIÂ boom.

Peter Steinberger

IN BRIEF:

  • The popular JSBin collaborative JavaScript pastebin went down for a few days and Remy Sharp shares the war story of what happened.

  • ğŸ”’ The OpenJS Foundation has shared an annual report covering its efforts in securing the JSÂ ecosystem.

  • Angular is changing components' default change detection strategy.

  • Both Astro and Svelte have shared monthly roundups of what'sÂ new.

RELEASES:

  • Node.js v25.6.0 (Current) â€“ async_hooks can now skip Promise hooks to reduce overhead. Plus, URL parsing now supports UnicodeÂ 17.

  • jQuery UI 1.14.2 â€“ The legacy UI library gets its first update in over a year and now works with jQueryÂ 4.0.

  • Bun v1.3.8 â€“ Say hello to native MarkdownÂ parsing.

  • Astro 5.17, ESLint 10.0.0-rc2, tRPC v11.9.0, Lexical 0.40.0, Reka UI 2.8 (formerly RadixÂ Vue)

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

â‰ï¸Â How Not to Parse Numbers in JavaScript â€” Why use a proper locale-aware API to parse numbers when you can hand-roll a maze of string splits, separator swaps, and implicit type coercions that silently break on edgeÂ cases?

Remy Porter (The Daily WTF)

ğŸ“‰Â Node.js 16 to 25 Benchmarked Version-by-Version â€” The jumps in performance in various areas are striking (with Node 25, especially), with other areas getting more modestÂ gains.

RepoFlow

A Practical Checklist for B2B Enterprise Readiness â€” Measure gaps in auth, admin UX, security, monitoring, and architecture for landing enterprise customers. DownloadÂ today!

Descope sponsor

Explicit Resource Management in JavaScript â€” You can use using for deterministic cleanup, calling Symbol.dispose/asyncDispose at scope exit without try/finally. A small fix for leaks and forgotten teardowns in streams, observers, locks, and similarÂ APIs.

Matt Smith

The History of C# and TypeScript with Anders Hejlsberg â€” GitHub interviewed the creator of both C# and TypeScript about his career, why TypeScript was created in the first place, some internal Microsoft politics, as well as the ongoing Go port of the TypeScriptÂ compiler. There's a video of the full interview, as well as 'seven learnings' boiled down in writtenÂ form.

GitHub

ğŸ“„ My Opinionated ESLint Setup for Vue Projects â€“ Packed with examples to pick and chooseÂ from. Alexander Opalic

ğŸ“„ A Scroll-Revealed WebGL Gallery with GSAP, Three.js, Astro and Barba.js â€“ Striking visual image reveal effect with a liveÂ demo. Chakib Mazouni

ğŸ“„ Predicting Math.random() in Firefox Using Z3 SMT-Solver Dennis Yurichev

ğŸ¤ Securing npm is Table Stakes Nicholas C. Zakas (Changelog Podcast)

ğŸ“„ Building a Simple RSS Aggregator with Astro Raymond Camden

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Heat.js 5.0: A Flexible Heat Map Rendering Solution â€” Generate customized interactive heatmaps (think GitHub contributions graph), or render heatmaps as lines and bar charts. The site is packed with demos to enjoy. GitHubÂ repo.

William Troup

Building an MCP Server? Don't Roll Your Own Auth â€” WorkOS AuthKit handles OAuth 2.1 flows so your MCP server just verifies tokens. Control which tools AI agentsÂ access.

WorkOS sponsor

ğŸ•’Â Croner 10.0: Cron-Style Triggers and Evaluation â€” Trigger functions on any cron schedule using cron syntax. It can also evaluate cron expressions to give you a list of upcoming times. v10.0 brings full OCPS (Open Cron Pattern Specification) 1.4 compliance and even more schedulingÂ options.

Hexagon

ğŸ—“ï¸Â DayFlow: A Full Calendar Component for React â€” A React-only feature-rich calendar component with drag-and-drop, multiple views, and all the usual GCal-style richness. Its infinite scrolling feature is nifty. GitHubÂ repo.

DayFlow Contributors

Tsonic: A TypeScript to C# Transpiler â€” The idea is for creating native executables that run on .NET. Iâ€™ve not tested it as Iâ€™m not in that ecosystem but itâ€™s an interestingÂ idea.

Jeswin

  • ğŸ“„ EmbedPDF 2.4 â€“ Framework-agnostic JavaScript PDF viewer. (Demo.)

  • JavaScriptKit v0.40 â€“ Swift framework for interacting with JS viaÂ WASM.

  • StackBlur.js 3.0 â€“ Long-standing Gaussian blur library; now usingÂ ESM.

  • Knip 5.83 â€“ Finds and fixes unused files, dependencies andÂ exports.

  • ğŸ“„ jsPDF 4.1 â€“ Generate PDFs directly in JavaScript. (Demo.)

  • qrcode.vue 3.8 â€“ Vue.js component to generate QRÂ codes.

  • focus-trap 8.0 â€“ Trap focus within a DOM node. (Demo.)

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting tidbits in the broader landscape:

  • GitHub is exploring solutions to tackle low-quality contributions, which could include giving you the option to disable PRs entirely or at least restrict them to collaborators. Got opinions? Join theÂ discussion.

  • How to throttle individual network requests in Chrome, rather than at a global level. Ideal for testing what happens when your dependencies load veryÂ slooooooowwwwwly....

  • ğŸ¤– OpenAI has released a desktop version of its agentic-coding Codex app. macOS only for now, though someone used Codex to port itself to Linux..Â ğŸ˜‚

  • âš ï¸ If you're a Windows user using the popular Notepad++ editor, you might want to double check your install as the project suffered a suspected state-sponsored hijack inÂ 2025.

  • svelteesp32 is a curious project for embedding Svelte, React, Angular or Vue frontends into ESP32 microcontrollerÂ apps.

#â€‹770 â€” January 27, 2026

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Introducing LibPDF: PDF Parsing and Generation from TypeScript â€” LibPDF bills itself as â€˜the PDF library TypeScript deservesâ€™ and supports parsing, modifying, signing and generating PDFs with a modern API in Node, Bun, and the browser. GitHubÂ repo.

Documenso

JavaScript Frameworks â€“ Heading into 2026 â€” The creator of SolidJS knows more than a thing or two about JS frameworks and has written an annual review of the scene for the past few years. Here, he picks on four areas of evolution, and says itâ€™s â€œan incredibly exciting time to be working on JavaScriptÂ frameworks.â€

Ryan Carniato

Still Writing Tests Manually? â€” Notion, Dropbox, Wiz, and LaunchDarkly have found a new testing paradigm - and they can't imagine working without it. Built by ex-Palantir engineers, Meticulous autonomously creates a continuously evolving suite of E2E UI tests that delivers near-exhaustive coverage with zero developerÂ effort.

Meticulous AI sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • Lea Verou has celebrated getting two ECMAScript proposals she's championed to stage 1 at TC39 this week: Composable Accessors and Alias Accessors. Rob Palmer also shares more proposal updates from the latest TC39 plenary.

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ The creator of Three.js (known as mrdoob) has created a Three.js-powered port of 1996's Quake â€“ here's the source. You can learn more about this project in this XÂ thread.

  • ğŸ“Š JSBenchmarks.com is a fresh attempt to benchmark several popular JavaScript frameworks. As always with benchmarks, use a critical eye, but the example apps are open to read or contributeÂ to.

RELEASES:

  • Node.js 25.5.0 (Current) â€“ Introduces a --build-sea option that simplifies the process of building single executableÂ applications.

  • Bun v1.3.7 â€“ The popular runtime updates its JavaScriptCore engine, leading to 35% faster async/await and ARM64 perf improvements. It also lands a new option to generate profiling data in Markdown format for easier sharing, plus native JSON5 and JSONL parsingÂ support.

  • Rolldown 1.0 RC â€“ Fast Rust-based bundler with a Rollup-compatible API and esbuild featureÂ parity.

  • npm v11.8.0, Emscripten 5.0, Neutralinojs 6.5.0

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

Porting 100k Lines from TypeScript to Rust in aÂ Month â€” A prolific JavaScript developer ported a PokÃ©mon battle simulator to Rust and shares his experiences and techniques used to work around issues where Claude Code would get bogged down in such a large task. He notes â€œLLM-based coding agents are such a great new toolâ€ but require â€œengineering expertise and constantÂ babysittingâ€.

Christopher Chedeau

Building a JavaScript Runtime in One Month â€” â€œWhat if I could build a JavaScript engine small enough to embed in a C program, but complete enough to actually run real code?â€ The end result is Ant.

theMackabu

Clerk MCP Server for AI Coding Assistants â€” Connect Claude, Cursor, or Copilot to Clerk's docs. Get working auth code instead of outdatedÂ patterns.

Clerk sponsor

Inside Turbopack: Building Faster by Building Less â€” If youâ€™re working on a large codebase, faster hot reloading, better scaling, and persistent caching are all quite desirable. Hereâ€™s how these things came about inÂ Turbopack.

Shew, Woodruff and Koppers (Vercel)

â–¶Â Â Bun Explained in 100 Seconds â€” The popular quick dev explainer channel tackles Bun at a highÂ level.

Fireship

ğŸ“„ Fixing a 6-Year-Old JavaScript Memory Leak in a Google Cloud Function Matt Zeunert (DebugBear)

ğŸ“„ Build a Dinosaur Runner Game with Deno, Part 4 â€“ The fourth part of an ongoing series on the official DenoÂ blog. Jo Franchetti

ğŸ“„ SPAs are a Performance Dead End Yegor Bugayenko

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Midscene.js: Remote Control for the Web, Mobile and Desktop Using VisionÂ Models â€” Provides a way to drive numerous platforms from JavaScript (including iOS) by using various integrations and a vision-capable model so you can write actions in a mixture of JavaScript and natural language and have themÂ performed.

ByteDance Inc.

ğŸ”„Â Travels 1.0: A Fast, Framework-Agnostic Undo/Redo Library â€” Allows you to add undo/redo functionality to apps like text editors, drawing tools, or other interactive software. Uses a memory efficient technique only storing changes, rather than full snapshots for eachÂ change.

Mutative

The #1 Time-Series Database Built on Postgres â€” TimescaleDB extends Postgres with hypertables, 95% compression, and continuous aggregates. Start building forÂ free.

Tiger Data sponsor

SonicJS 2.7: Perf-Focused Edge-Native Headless CMS for CloudflareÂ Workers â€” A production-ready CMS built specifically for the edge. GitHubÂ repo.

SonicJS Team

ğŸ¤–Â Mastra 1.0: An AI Framework from the Former Gatsby Team â€” An all-in-one framework (homepage) for building AI-powered apps andÂ agents.

Sam Bhagwat

  • Storybook 10.2 â€“ The frontend workshop for building UI components gets some UI and story authoringÂ improvements.

  • ğŸ¥ Mediabunny 1.31.0 â€“ Media toolkit for reading, writing, and converting video and audio files, directly in theÂ browser.

  • Cheerio v1.2 â€“ Fast, flexible HTML and XML parser and DOM manipulationÂ library.

  • eslint-plugin-regexp 3.0 â€“ Plugin for finding regex mistakes and styleÂ violations.

  • React Timeline Editor 1.0 â€“ Component to build timeline-based editors. (Examples.)

  • ğŸ“Š Billboard.js 3.18.0 â€“ Flexible JavaScript chart library based on D3.js.

  • Feedsmith 2.9 â€“ Feed parser and generator for popular feedÂ formats.

  • Typed.js v3.0 â€“ Typing animation library. (GPLÂ licensed.)

  • Regle v1.17 â€“ Headless form validation library forÂ Vue.

Some other interesting tidbits in the broader landscape:

  • OpenAI's Michael Bolin wrote a thorough technical review of how its OpenAI Codex agent works. Invaluable reading for anyone trying to implement their own coding agent or even if you just want to know how they do theirÂ thing.

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ A group of developers has ported Super Monkey Ball to the Web. Here's the source if you're intrigued - it has surprisingly fewÂ dependencies.
